thread.title: North East exports continue to grow but remains reliant on the EU

author: Jonathon Manning
title: North East exports continue to grow but remains reliant on the EU
text:
North East exports continue to grow but remains reliant on the EU Trade with EU countries made up over 60% of the total exports made by North East companies Share A container ship (Image: PA) Share Get business updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
The North East economy added an extra £250m to its export figures during the last quarter, with the majority of the increase was derived from trade with the EU . 
Businesses in the region exported a total of £3.16bn worth of goods and services during the three months ending September 2017, £248m higher than during the same period in the previous year. 
The figures, which were taken from the HMRC Regional trade statistics, represent an 8.5% increase compared to 2016. Overall UK exports grew by 11.6%. Jack Simpson, policy adviser, North East England Chamber of Commerce 
Jack Simpson, policy adviser at the North East England Chamber of Commerce , said: “While growth has been positive, it has been in the predictable and established markets. To help boost global trade, it is essential that the Government encourages and supports business in their exporting missions. 
“This will help business access new global opportunities, and promote growth and innovation in their sector. Read More Multimillion-pound revamp at Newcastle's Royal Grammar School moves into new phase 
“It is really positive to see the North East continue to grow in these globally uncertain times, but we believe with the right support, these figures could be even better.” 
The EU remained the North East’s biggest trading partner, with over 60% of total exports being shipped to EU countries. But trade to many regions outside of the EU fell, causing concern that many companies could suffer if the UK does not manage to secure a strong trade deal during Brexit negotiations. 
North East exports to Latin America and the Caribbean suffered the most, after falling by 23%. Meanwhile trade to non-EU countries in Western Europe fell by 14%, and exports to North America dipped 6%. Read More 
But the news was not all doom and gloom, with the statistics also showing that trade to the Middle East and North Africa increased by almost 30%. Exports to Asia and Oceania also grew by 15.5%. 
The reliance on exporting to the EU comes as the negotiations for leaving the trading block continue. 
On Friday, European Union leaders approved plans to move on to the second stage of Brexit negotiations. European Council president Donald Tusk said the EU would now work with Theresa May to get more clarity on what the Government wants from the UK’s post-Brexit relationship with the union.
